variant.bodyText: Books listed below that are marked with a have been selected for review in a future issue, and reviewers have been assigned to each. Authors and publishers who wish their books to be considered for review in Com- putational Linguistics should send a copy to the book review editor, Graeme Hirst, De- partment of Computer Science, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada M5S 1A4. All books received will be listed, but not all can be re- viewed. Readers who wish to review books for the journal should write, outlining their qualifi- cations, to the book review editor at the ad- dress above or send electronic mail to gh@cs.toronto.edu. Obviously, we cannot pro- mise the availability of books in anyone's ex- act area of interest. KR'91: Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning Cambridge, MA, April 1991 James Allen, Richard Fikes, and Erik Sandewall (editors) (University of Rochester, Stanford University, and University of Linkoping) San Mateo, CA: Morgan Kaufmann, 1991, xi + 609 pp. Paperbound, ISBN 1-55860-165-1 tCognitive Models of Speech Processing Gerry T.M. Altmann (editor) (University of Sussex) Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 1990, x + 540 pp. (The ACL—MIT Press Series in Natural Language Processing) Hardbound, ISBN 0-262-01117-4, $55.00 Neurocomputing 2: Directions for Research James A. Anderson, Andras Pellionisz, and Edward Rosenfeld (editors) (Brown University, New York University, and Intelligence) Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 1990, xxviii + 727 pp. Hardbound, ISBN 0-262-01119-0, $60.00 Modeling Legal Argument: Representing Cases with Hypotheticals Kevin Ashley (University of Pittsburgh) Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 1990, xiii + 329 pp. (Artificial Intelligence and Legal Reasoning Series) Hardbound, ISBN 0-262-01114-X, $39.95 Artificial Vision for Mobile Robots: Stereo Vision and Multisensory Perception Nicholas Ayache (INRIA) Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 1991, xiii + 342 pp. (Originally published as Vision Stereoscopique
variant.table: et Perception Multisensorielle, InterEditions, Paris, 1989; translated by Peter T. Sander) (Artificial Intelligence Series) Hardbound, ISBN 0-262-01124-7, $45.00 Types of A-Dependencies Guglielmo Cinque (University of Venice) Cambridge, MA: The MIT Press, 1990, xvi + 223 pp. (Linguistic Inquiry Monograph 17) Paperbound, ISBN 0-262-53089-9, $16.95 A Many-Valued Approach to Deduction and Reasoning for Artificial Intelligence Cary G. deBessonet (Louisiana State Law Institute and Southern University) Boston: Kluwer Academic Publishers, 1991, xviii + 248 pp. (The Kluwer International Series in
variant.bodyText: Engineering and Computer Science) Hardbound, ISBN 0-7923-9138-1, $62.50, £36.25, Dfl 130.00 Hypermedia and Literary Studies Paul Delany and George P.
